author: Mill, John Stuart

text: OF WHAT SORT OF PROOF THE PRINCIPLE OF UTILITY IS SUSCEPTIBLE.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It has already been remarked, that questions of ultimate ends do not
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: admit of proof, in the ordinary acceptation of the term. To be incapable
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of proof by reasoning is common to all first principles; to the first
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: premises of our knowledge, as well as to those of our conduct. But the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: former, being matters of fact, may be the subject of a direct appeal to
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the faculties which judge of fact--namely, our senses, and our internal
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consciousness. Can an appeal be made to the same faculties on questions
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of practical ends? Or by what other faculty is cognizance taken of them?
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Questions about ends are, in other words, questions what things are
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: desirable. The utilitarian doctrine is, that happiness is desirable, and
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the only thing desirable, as an end; all other things being only
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: desirable as means to that end. What ought to be required of this
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: doctrine--what conditions is it requisite that the doctrine should
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: fulfil--to make good its claim to be believed?
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: The only proof capable of being given that an object is visible, is that
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: people actually see it. The only proof that a sound is audible, is that
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: people hear it: and so of the other sources of our experience. In like
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: manner, I apprehend, the sole evidence it is possible to produce that
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: anything is desirable, is that people do actually desire it. If the end
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which the utilitarian doctrine proposes to itself were not, in theory
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and in practice, acknowledged to be an end, nothing could ever convince
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: any person that it was so. No reason can be given why the general
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: happiness is desirable, except that each person, so far as he believes
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it to be attainable, desires his own happiness. This, however, being a
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: fact, we have not only all the proof which the case admits of, but all
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which it is possible to require, that happiness is a good: that each
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: person's happiness is a good to that person, and the general happiness,
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: therefore, a good to the aggregate of all persons. Happiness has made
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: out its title as _one_ of the ends of conduct, and consequently one of
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the criteria of morality.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But it has not, by this alone, proved itself to be the sole criterion.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: To do that, it would seem, by the same rule, necessary to show, not only
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: that people desire happiness, but that they never desire anything else.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Now it is palpable that they do desire things which, in common language,
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: are decidedly distinguished from happiness. They desire, for example,
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: virtue, and the absence of vice, no less really than pleasure and the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: absence of pain. The desire of virtue is not as universal, but it is as
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: authentic a fact, as the desire of happiness. And hence the opponents of
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the utilitarian standard deem that they have a right to infer that there
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: are other ends of human action besides happiness, and that happiness is
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: not the standard of approbation and disapprobation.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: But does the utilitarian doctrine deny that people desire virtue, or
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: maintain that virtue is not a thing to be desired? The very reverse. It
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: maintains not only that virtue is to be desired, but that it is to be
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: desired disinterestedly, for itself. Whatever may be the opinion of
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: utilitarian moralists as to the original conditions by which virtue is
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: made virtue; however they may believe (as they do) that actions and
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: dispositions are only virtuous because they promote another end than
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: virtue; yet this being granted, and it having been decided, from
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: considerations of this description, what _is_ virtuous, they not only
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: place virtue at the very head of the things which are good as means to
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the ultimate end, but they also recognise as a psychological fact the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: possibility of its being, to the individual, a good in itself, without
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: looking to any end beyond it; and hold, that the mind is not in a right
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: state, not in a state conformable to Utility, not in the state most
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: conducive to the general happiness, unless it does love virtue in this
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: manner--as a thing desirable in itself, even although, in the individual
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: instance, it should not produce those other desirable consequences which
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it tends to produce, and on account of which it is held to be virtue.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: This opinion is not, in the smallest degree, a departure from the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: Happiness principle. The ingredients of happiness are very various, and
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: each of them is desirable in itself, and not merely when considered as
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: swelling an aggregate. The principle of utility does not mean that any
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: given pleasure, as music, for instance, or any given exemption from
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: pain, as for example health, are to be looked upon as means to a
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: collective something termed happiness, and to be desired on that
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: account. They are desired and desirable in and for themselves; besides
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: being means, they are a part of the end. Virtue, according to the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: utilitarian doctrine, is not naturally and originally part of the end,
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: but it is capable of becoming so; and in those who love it
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: disinterestedly it has become so, and is desired and cherished, not as a
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: means to happiness, but as a part of their happiness.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: To illustrate this farther, we may remember that virtue is not the only
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: thing, originally a means, and which if it were not a means to anything
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: else, would be and remain indifferent, but which by association with
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: what it is a means to, comes to be desired for itself, and that too with
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the utmost intensity. What, for example, shall we say of the love of
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: money? There is nothing originally more desirable about money than about
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: any heap of glittering pebbles. Its worth is solely that of the things
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which it will buy; the desires for other things than itself, which it is
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a means of gratifying. Yet the love of money is not only one of the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: strongest moving forces of human life, but money is, in many cases,
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: desired in and for itself; the desire to possess it is often stronger
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: than the desire to use it, and goes on increasing when all the desires
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: which point to ends beyond it, to be compassed by it, are falling off.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It may be then said truly, that money is desired not for the sake of an
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: end, but as part of the end. From being a means to happiness, it has
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: come to be itself a principal ingredient of the individual's conception
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of happiness. The same may be said of the majority of the great objects
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of human life--power, for example, or fame; except that to each of these
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: there is a certain amount of immediate pleasure annexed, which has at
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: least the semblance of being naturally inherent in them; a thing which
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: cannot be said of money. Still, however, the strongest natural
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: attraction, both of power and of fame, is the immense aid they give to
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the attainment of our other wishes; and it is the strong association
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: thus generated between them and all our objects of desire, which gives
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to the direct desire of them the intensity it often assumes, so as in
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: some characters to surpass in strength all other desires. In these cases
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the means have become a part of the end, and a more important part of it
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: than any of the things which they are means to. What was once desired as
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: an instrument for the attainment of happiness, has come to be desired
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for its own sake. In being desired for its own sake it is, however,
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: desired as part of happiness. The person is made, or thinks he would be
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: made, happy by its mere possession; and is made unhappy by failure to
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: obtain it. The desire of it is not a different thing from the desire of
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: happiness, any more than the love of music, or the desire of health.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: They are included in happiness. They are some of the elements of which
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the desire of happiness is made up. Happiness is not an abstract idea,
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: but a concrete whole; and these are some of its parts. And the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: utilitarian standard sanctions and approves their being so. Life would
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be a poor thing, very ill provided with sources of happiness, if there
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: were not this provision of nature, by which things originally
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: indifferent, but conducive to, or otherwise associated with, the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: satisfaction of our primitive desires, become in themselves sources of
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: pleasure more valuable than the primitive pleasures, both in permanency,
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: in the space of human existence that they are capable of covering, and
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: even in intensity. Virtue, according to the utilitarian conception, is a
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: good of this description. There was no original desire of it, or motive
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: to it, save its conduciveness to pleasure, and especially to protection
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: from pain. But through the association thus formed, it may be felt a
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: good in itself, and desired as such with as great intensity as any other
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: good; and with this difference between it and the love of money, of
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: power, or of fame, that all of these may, and often do, render the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: individual noxious to the other members of the society to which he
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: belongs, whereas there is nothing which makes him so much a blessing to
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: them as the cultivation of the disinterested, love of virtue. And
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consequently, the utilitarian standard, while it tolerates and approves
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: those other acquired desires, up to the point beyond which they would be
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: more injurious to the general happiness than promotive of it, enjoins
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: and requires the cultivation of the love of virtue up to the greatest
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: strength possible, as being above all things important to the general
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: happiness.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: It results from the preceding considerations, that there is in reality
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: nothing desired except happiness. Whatever is desired otherwise than as
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: a means to some end beyond itself, and ultimately to happiness, is
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: desired as itself a part of happiness, and is not desired for itself
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: until it has become so. Those who desire virtue for its own sake, desire
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: it either because the consciousness of it is a pleasure, or because the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: consciousness of being without it is a pain, or for both reasons united;
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: as in truth the pleasure and pain seldom exist separately, but almost
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: always together, the same person feeling pleasure in the degree of
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: virtue attained, and pain in not having attained more. If one of these
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: gave him no pleasure, and the other no pain, he would not love or desire
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: virtue, or would desire it only for the other benefits which it might
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: produce to himself or to persons whom he cared for.

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: We have now, then, an answer to the question, of what sort of proof the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: principle of utility is susceptible. If the opinion which I have now
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: stated is psychologically true--if human nature is so constituted as to
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: desire nothing which is not either a part of happiness or a means of
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: happiness, we can have no other proof, and we require no other, that
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: these are the only things desirable. If so, happiness is the sole end of
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: human action, and the promotion of it the test by which to judge of all
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: human conduct; from whence it necessarily follows that it must be the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: criterion of morality, since a part is included in the whole.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: And now to decide whether this is really so; whether mankind do desire
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: nothing for itself but that which is a pleasure to them, or of which the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: absence is a pain; we have evidently arrived at a question of fact and
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: experience, dependent, like all similar questions, upon evidence. It can
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: only be determined by practised self-consciousness and self-observation,
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: assisted by observation of others. I believe that these sources of
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: evidence, impartially consulted, will declare that desiring a thing and
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: finding it pleasant, aversion to it and thinking of it as painful, are
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: phenomena entirely inseparable, or rather two parts of the same
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: phenomenon; in strictness of language, two different modes of naming the
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: same psychological fact: that to think of an object as desirable (unless
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: for the sake of its consequences), and to think of it as pleasant, are

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: one and the same thing; and that to desire anything, except in
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: impossibility.
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: So obvious does this appear to me, that I expect it will hardly be
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: disputed: and the objection made will be, not that desire can possibly
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: be directed to anything ultimately except pleasure and exemption from
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: pain, but that the will is a different thing from desire; that a person
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: of confirmed virtue, or any other person whose purposes are fixed,
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: carries out his purposes without any thought of the pleasure he has in
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: contemplating them, or expects to derive from their fulfilment; and

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: persists in acting on them, even though these pleasures are much

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: elsewhere, as positively and emphatically as any one. Will, the active

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Utilitarianism

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: deliberately and consistently any determinate end. The distinction

author: Mill, John Stuart

text: between will and desire thus understood, is an authentic and highly

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Utilitarianism

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Utilitarianism

text: desire only because we will it. It is not the less true that will, in
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

text: the beginning, is entirely produced by desire; including in that term
title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart

title: Utilitarianism
author: Mill, John Stuart

author: Mill, John Stuart
